Peter Pan.Action: We are flying--up the Thames River; Peter Pan’s presence is implied by the memory of him coming and going through Wendy’s nursery window, suggesting ongoing agency and capability to transcend normal boundaries.
No direct action described; referenced only indirectly and nostalgically through Wendy’s memory and Liza’s hopeful speech, indicating a lack of current assertive behavior.
Shows worry and nervousness about flying but is open about his fear and receives a sympathetic hug from Moira.
Worries out loud about Jack hitting the ceiling and the oxygen masks falling out, showing concern for his son.
Shows extreme fear of flying, holding on tightly and sweating bullets, appearing nervous and worried.
Attempts to warn his son about the oxygen masks and potential danger of the ball, showing attentiveness to safety.
Spills his drink by reacting poorly to the ball, losing control over the situation.
Asks for help ('Switch') and tries to manage his discomfort under stress, indicating self-awareness but limited coping ability.
Verbalizes his panic openly ('I’m not going to make it to my next birthday'), showing lack of confidence and composure.
Carefully tightens Maggie's seatbelt despite her discomfort, then loosens it when she complains.
Encourages Maggie to show him her drawing and tries to engage with her positively despite the crisis.
Gives reassuring but honest response about the lack of parachutes, showing sincerity.
Herds family and carry-on bags grimly through customs, clearly stressed but focused on safety.
Instant panic and searching loudly for missing daughter Maggie, showing immediate concern.
Takes Maggie's hand and flushes red after the bathroom incident, showing embarrassment but protective affection.
Moves Jack behind the yellow line with Maggie and Moira as if Jack were radioactive, indicating social discomfort or exclusion of family member.
Without looking up, orders Maggie to keep her head inside the taxi window, showing a brusque and inattentive behavior towards child’s curiosity.
Reaches out and grabs Jack's hand without looking up, a subtle gesture of connection towards Jack.
Pales and panics when Maggie is missing, drops all the bags, causing a public scene.
Shows quick recognition of the problem when Maggie is unaccounted for and immediately searches for her.
Keeps control by taking Maggie's hand once found, showing some recovery from initial panic.
Moves Jack behind the yellow line by a small margin, displaying cautious behavior but seeming overly controlling or anxious.
Is engrossed with calculating exchange rates on an electronic filofax during taxi ride, showing engagement with practical and complex tasks.
Tells Maggie to 'head inside' without looking, somewhat curtly, and shows minimal attention to children's curiosity.
Pulls Jack down from walking on the garden wall to keep him safe, smooths Maggie’s clothes, and reminds children about manners
Greeted by Uncle Tootles who slams the door on him; Peter remains calm and tries again
Lingers staring up at the Nursery window, showing hesitation or concern
Pulls Jack down from walking on a garden wall to prevent him from falling, gives clear instructions to children about manners and behavior, calmly handles arrivals and interactions at the house.
Lingers and stares up at the nursery window, possibly indicating hesitation or fear.
Motions sternly to Jack to come over, maintaining order and control among children.
Stares Jack into silence after Jack insults Maggie; enforces boundaries calmly.
Whips Jack’s ball cap from his head impulsively, showing a lack of tact.
Nudges Maggie to perform something practiced, showing leadership and subtle encouragement.
Encourages Jack politely with a nod and admonishes kids for manners, showing gentle guidance.
Pecks Granny Wendy on the cheek, acknowledges her warmly despite jetlag and stress.
Fumbles nervously preparing for an event, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Helps Moira by zipping up her dress and participates in tender moment, indicating care and affection.
Focuses intently on work tension while remaining emotionally available to Moira.
Does not engage directly with the children in the scene and is described as making every one crazy when he does see them, possibly indicating frustration or lack of patience.
Nods to Jack encouragingly, showing leadership and confidence.
Intervenes to correct the children's manners, demonstrating social awareness and control.
Manages multiple stressful tasks—on the phone with urgency while preparing for an event—showing ability to multitask under pressure.
Fumbles fastening his tuxedo studs, indicating slight nervousness or lack of composure in small tasks.
Cradles the phone and zips Moira's dress while maintaining urgent communication, showing practical problem-solving and care.
Appears too busy and under stress, resulting in tension and emotional strain, possibly neglecting personal connections with children.
Expresses love for his children and Moira despite a rough day.
Dismisses concerns about his wellbeing and denies having problems.
Despite external pressures and worries from family, Peter maintains a confident denial of problems ('C/mon--I do not.'), showing a certain assertiveness.
Struggles internally with stress and cannot recall the last time he had a good day, indicating possible emotional overwhelm and lack of effective coping mechanisms.
Encourages Maggie to go to bed on time and maintains a playful tone
Protectively slams and locks the window to keep the children safe
Dismisses Maggie's concern about fairytales and insists on no more stories
Lunges to pull Jack away from the open window and locks it securely to prevent danger.
Reminds children to get their body clocks back on schedule and enforces bedtime routine.
Tries to avoid thinking about the potentially fatal consequence of a child falling out of the window, showing some emotional discomfort.
Dismisses Maggie’s concern about windows not letting fairytale characters in without engaging with her imagination.
Tells Maggie to go to sleep dismissively, cutting off her enthusiasm for fairytales.
Helps Granny Wendy up from the floor and urges her not to be late for an important event.
Responds with grim appreciation to Maggie's handmade parachute gift, seeming awkward but thankful.
Calmly dismisses Maggie's doubt about Santa Claus, maintaining a confident and playful attitude.
Helps Granny Wendy up off the floor and urges her not to be late for an important event, showing responsibility and awareness of social situations.
Inspects the parachute gift with puzzlement, showing some uncertainty or lack of understanding about its purpose.
Smoothes Jack’s hair despite Jack’s rejection, lingers to check on kids, leaves door ajar for safety, sighs with relief after ensuring children are safe in bed.
Defensive reaction to Granny Wendy’s comment about missing children growing up, showing tension and discomfort.
Expresses worry and concern about his children’s safety, feeling burdened and protective.
Asks Granny Wendy why his kids seem to put themselves in danger, shows frustration and helplessness.
Smoothes Jack's hair, checks the window to ensure kids are safe, leaves door ajar for reassurance, shows care and vigilance.
Expresses frustration and confusion about why his kids take dangerous risks despite his vigilance.
Feels burdened and tense about parenthood, showing emotional vulnerability but not loss of capability.
Fails to connect with Jack, who is rejecting him, indicating a gap in emotional intelligence or communication.
Paces nervously, struggles to express genuine emotions while praising Wendy, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Paces nervously in the wings, going over his notes, practicing a gracious gesture and delivery.
Struggles at the dais, finding unexpected emotions as he speaks in front of a large audience.
Politely engages with the audience, encouraging them to stand in tribute, showing leadership and confidence.
Appears somewhat disconnected from the danger unfolding (cold icy wind, screams, assault on Liza) suggesting a lapse in immediate situational awareness.
Steadies Granny Wendy when she sways from an unseen force.
Helps an exhausted Granny Wendy out of the car, showing concern.
Urgently checks Liza’s condition and tries to help her after she is injured.
Frustrated and desperate slamming against the nursery door to rescue the children.
Steadies Granny Wendy when she is swaying, showing calmness and support under pressure.
Quickly reads and interprets the threatening note from Captain Hook.
Responds immediately to the emergency by rushing upstairs to check on Liza and examining her condition.
Attempts to break down the nursery door urgently to rescue the children.
Does not hesitate or show confusion when confronting unfolding threats, acting decisively.
Freezes in shock and shows acute vertigo when ascending the ladder to rescue Tootles, hugging every rung and afraid to look down.
Attempts to calm Tootles by whispering reassurances despite his own fear.
Comforts and holds Tootles tightly when he is terrified and struggling, tries to keep him talking and calm.
Shows pity for Tootles, the old man at end of life, indicating empathy.
Carefully guides Moira out of granny Wendy’s room respecting the doctor’s indication, shows consideration.
Stays alone with Wendy at her request, showing loyalty and willingness to provide support in her grief.
Calmly tries to keep Tootles focused and gathers information about missing children despite chaos.
Holds onto Tootles for dear life while descending with safety line.
Listens and responds empathetically to Wendy’s grief, respecting her wishes to stay alone.
Takes Wendy's hand tenderly and tries to comfort her as she drifts off.
Shows confusion and detachment, thinking Wendy is delirious rather than accepting her truths.
Pats Wendy's hands reassuringly and offers to get Moira to help her.
Takes Wendy's hand tenderly and listens intently to her revelations despite confusion, showing emotional attentiveness and openness.
Appears confused and unsure about Wendy's cryptic statements and his lost memory, indicating a lack of clarity and control over his situation.
Reassures Wendy by trying to calm her and promising to get Moira, showing decisiveness and caring leadership in a difficult moment.
Fails to grasp the full meaning or implications of Wendy's warnings about forgetting and growing up, suggesting gaps in understanding critical personal issues.
Embraces Moira, holding her tight, trying to make it all go away
Stares stone-faced at the book, does not respond to Gran's plea
Drinks heavily, appears catatonic and grief-stricken
Stares stonefaced at the illustration of himself, unable to respond or take immediate action.
Exits the bedroom exhausted, signaling emotional and physical drain but also persistence in engaging with the situation.
Attempts to comfort Moira by embracing her despite his own grief and helplessness.
Drinks heavily, pouring and chugging multiple scotches in apparent despair and avoidance.
Sits catatonic with Moira, waiting passively for any developments, showing inaction during a crisis.
Hears the inspector’s report and shows emotional distress but no immediate proactive response to the threat.
Sits alone in the nursery, struggles with grief and loss, openly breaks down crying, showing vulnerability and sorrow for the children lost.
Drinks alcohol alone, is strung out and uses dark humor addressing imaginary children, indicating emotional numbness and avoidance.
Scoffs at and dismisses the idea of a talking faerie, shows skepticism and disbelief.
Retreats and slams door, hyperventilating and protecting himself from intense light, indicating fear and self-preservation rather than openness.
Swats at the attacking light and retreats into the bathroom, slamming the door and hyperventilating, covering his ears due to pain and distress.
Peeks cautiously through the keyhole to assess the situation (seeing Tinkerbell and hearing bells), showing some situational awareness.
Clutches his head and reacts with apparent regret after possibly hurting Tink; claps to help save her despite reluctance.
Says 'I DO NOT BELIEVE IN FAERIES!' loudly, causing harm to Tink’s wellbeing.
Walks away from Tink, rubbing his temples, showing frustration and avoidance of emotional confrontation.
Shows signs of internal conflict and some care by engaging in saving Tink despite his gruffness.
Attempts to intervene and help Tink by clapping despite his hesitant and semi-conscious state.
Denies belief in fairies causing harm and unintentionally harms Tink, showing poor awareness and judgement.
Expresses frustration and fatigue, indicating possible loss of confidence or clarity.
Attempts to avoid going to Neverland and flying, showing fear and reluctance to engage in adventurous behavior
Sheds Peter Pan identity and resists Tink's efforts to rekindle past heroic traits
Subtly shows concern when asking about his kids and reacting soberly to Tink's words
Honest with the neighbor about his identity, introducing Miss Bell.
Chastises Tink harshly by calling her a drunk and criticizes her appearance ('Lardo').
Shows vulnerability about flying, admitting fear and sickness.
Attempts to fly despite fear of heights and successfully manages to stop his fall by using a makeshift parachute and ascends into the sky.
Forgets how to fly initially and needs Tink to remind him of the basics, showing initial hesitation and insecurity.
Jokes about hallucinating while trying to fly, showing a casual or dismissive attitude rather than focused determination.
Communicates clearly and confidently with the neighbor, identifying himself and Miss Bell.
Loses his balance and falls off the ledge, indicating a momentary lapse in coordination or awareness.
Allows dirty boys to poke and attempt to steal from him without immediate retaliation, showing tolerance before reacting.
Does not show hostility when waking up disoriented and in pain, remains focused on reorienting himself.
Mumbles and calls out seemingly for friends when delirious, indicating concern for others.
Calls out for help when attacked by the Lost Boys, showing vulnerability and trust in others.
Is mocked and mimicked by the Lost Boys after asking for help, indicating a lack of control or authority.
Faces hostile treatment calmly, tries to assert his identity (I am not a pirate, I am a lawyer) despite confusion and aggression from the boys.
Leads the count with the Lost Boys before they fire on him, seeming to accept the game's violence without protest.
Sitting down casually and having an animated conversation with himself, appearing somewhat distracted and not commanding attention actively.
Reacting defensively to comments about his age and appearance, trying to maintain dignity despite clear physical decline.
Shoos Ziggy back like an annoyed parent, demonstrating some assertiveness and confidence in his familiar environment.
Is doubted by the Lost Boys and Rufio because of his physical condition and apparent lack of vigor.
Acknowledges the need to fly again but admits they are still working on that part, showing some self-awareness and honesty but also a current incapacity.
Shakes his head and mumbles, waving others away, attempts to avoid conflict.
Calm and resolute in the face of aggression and insult.
Pushes madly through the Lost Boys in panic, showing vulnerability and fear.
Calls others not real and dismisses their existence with 'No offense.'
Calmly stands and tries to reason despite hostility; shows mental clarity by recognizing the unreality of the situation and staying resolute.
Panics and runs blindly into the jungle after being attacked and cut; fails to respond with control or strategy.
Clutches Tink's hand when falling down a steep hill, showing concern and care.
Is awed and sincere in his reaction to Neverland's beauty, showing openness and wonder.
Appears vulnerable and struggling to express himself honestly to Tink.
Acknowledges Tink as 'real' and addresses her sincerely, indicating trust and respect.
Leads the Lost Boys into the jungle with confidence and determination.
Runs through dense undergrowth, clutching Tink's hand, but falls and tumbles down a steep hill to a precarious edge.
Kneels, awed by the breathtaking view before him, showing a moment of reverence and emotional intelligence.
Struggles mentally, fogged in trying to reason about Tink's identity, showing confusion and difficulty with clear judgment.
Eventually acknowledges and names Tink, demonstrating some clarity and willingness to confront reality.
Plans to find Hook and talk to him to work things out like adults instead of taking immediate violent action.
Refuses to fly or fight immediately, insisting 'I'm still me' and showing hesitation to jump into battle.
Shows confusion and disbelief about the kidnapping of his children, demonstrating concern and sincerity.
Analyzes the enemy ship with detailed knowledge of its armaments and capabilities.
Refuses to fly or fight Hook directly, instead planning to 'talk it out' like an adult despite the clear danger.
Immediately sets off in search of Hook and his children with determination and clear purpose.
Fails to accept the reality of the situation and rationally adapts, demonstrating disbelief and mental confusion.
Slows at the sights and the mass of Pirates, heading into the square like he’s going to the bank, ignoring Tink’s warning.
Responds to Tink's critique with calmness, dusting his shirt and smoothing his hair rather than reacting aggressively.
Escapes from a pursuing pirate while Tink silently lets him pass.
Heads into the pirate town square confidently, like going to the bank, showing calmness amidst chaos.
Dismisses Tink's criticism and cleans himself up before disappearing around the corner, showing self-awareness and control.
Is pulled back by Tink and delayed briefly, indicating some lack of focus or heedlessness.
Runs for his life pursued by a pirate, implying he is outmatched or caught off-guard.
Reacting with horror upon seeing enslaved children and recognizing that they could be his own—marching onto the pirate ship determinedly.
Climbs aboard Hook’s ship with other pirates despite being overwhelmed, maintains composure and awareness of surroundings.
Passively watches the stadium-style pirate wave pass by without engaging or reacting.
Overwhelmed by the hostile environment and the pirates' chants.
Hangs on the gunwale badly shaken by the violent behavior of pirates; he does not retaliate or respond aggressively.
Insists 'Wait...Not yet...' despite being shaken and prompted to leave, showing resolve but possibly putting himself or others at risk.
Hangs on the gunwale badly shaken and is hesitant, needing Tink to urge him to leave.
Despite being shaken, insists to wait and does not immediately flee.
Is horrified to see children chained and begging for food, mouths their names silently, feels helpless to protect them.
Tries to push through the pirates to help the captive children despite danger.
Strains to get a better view of the children chained in the hold, shows clear horror and silent mouthing of their names, feeling helpless to protect them.
Tries to push through the crowd of pirates in an attempt to reach and potentially rescue the captives.
Tink pulls the seat of his pants telling him he’s not ready, implying a hesitation or lack of preparedness.
Peter blushes when mocked, showing vulnerability.
Stands motionless and does not retaliate when provoked by Hook.
Admits he cannot fight and expresses desire only to get his kids back.
Offers to pay Hook reasonably rather than respond with violence.
Does not display friendliness toward Hook, but shows sincere and peaceful intentions.
Fails to use any warmth toward Hook's aggression but does not escalate conflict.
Stands motionless and does not engage when challenged by Hook.
Admits he does not have a sword and cannot fight Hook.
Attempts to reason with Hook and offers a checkbook to resolve the conflict peacefully.
Attempts to reason calmly, asks about a cash machine rather than escalating conflict.
Stares in horror when children are threatened; demands that his kids be released.
Does not physically retaliate when attacked or captured; shows restraint despite provocation.
Asks if there is a cash machine, showing a lack of awareness about his situation and surroundings.
Attempts to negotiate or reason in a tense and hostile situation despite being vulnerable.
Shows hesitation and surprise when confronted and captured by pirates, and protests but does not resist or escape.
Wobbles nervously on the plank, showing vulnerability and fear of falling.
Does not directly confront Hook or react aggressively in this moment, showing restraint.
Attempts to appear grateful while retreating despite hostile treatment from Hook.
Fails to fly, showing vulnerability and genuine sadness.
No aggressive or boastful response to Hook's insults and mockery.
Fails to fly and plummets into the sea, appearing helpless and unable to perform a fundamental skill associated with himself.
Attempts to look grateful and inch back up the plank despite hostile surroundings, showing some presence of mind.
Sinks struggling, slowly drowning and blacks out, showing inability to save himself from danger underwater.
Responds to the baby’s cry by waking up from unconsciousness, showing resilience and awareness.
Wendy shows strong emotional attachment and belief in Peter’s return; Peter responds to her presence.
Appears unconscious and passive, showing no active caring or interaction.
Responds weakly and vulnerably with 'Mother?' after nearly drowning, showing reliance and openness.
Allows Maidens to caress him, embarrassed but not rejecting their attention.
Coughs up water and gasps for air after almost drowning, responding to the Nautilus shell rescue.
Appears glassy eyed, with no signs of life prior to rescue, indicating initial incapacitation.
Asks 'Am I...dead?' showing confusion about his condition.
Responds to care from the Maidens despite embarrassment, indicating some situational awareness and recovery.
Admits he cannot fly or fight anymore, shows vulnerability and insecurity.
Allows the mermaids to touch and tease him, reacts with embarrassment but does not push them away.
Shows openness to reconnecting with his younger self when looking at his reflection.
Responds to mermaids' attention with a naughty devilish grin and joyful cannonball leap into the lagoon, displaying playfulness and openness.
Looks around nervously to see if his parents are watching before acting freely, indicating some self-consciousness but no rejection of companionship.
Leaps confidently into the lagoon full of adoring Mermaids, showing exuberance and courage.
Looks around nervously like a child before jumping, indicating some insecurity or self-consciousness despite his bravery.
